hero.heading: Dùthchas Arainn
hero.content: A community-owned approach to sustainable land management on Arran

sections.heading: Dùthchas Arainn is a Community Benefit Society established to hold land and assets in community ownership for the benefit of Arran's people. We're working to create a sustainable future for our island through woodland crofting, natural conservation, and cultural heritage preservation.
Become a Member - Before May 1st!
content: We're building a diverse community of members who share our vision for Arran. As a member, you'll help shape our priorities and contribute to our collective goals. Don't miss the May 1st deadline to become a founding member!
Membership is open to:
• Community Members (KA27 residents)
• Supporter Members (anyone outside KA27)

sections.heading: Exciting New Opportunity: Former Bank of Scotland Building in Brodick
content: We're moving forward with plans to acquire the former Bank of Scotland branch in Brodick as a community-owned environmental hub. This central location would provide:
• An environmental and sustainability hub with resources for the whole Arran community
• Flexible co-working space and meeting rooms for local organisations and remote workers
• A vibrant community venue in the former banking hall for events, workshops and gatherings
• A visible presence for environmental initiatives in the heart of Brodick

We're developing investment options at various levels (potentially from £500 to £5,000) with corresponding benefits for community supporters. Investment shares would be withdrawable if the project doesn't proceed. Full prospectus coming soon!

sections.heading: Our Current Focus: Glen Cloy
content: We're also working toward a community asset transfer of woodland in Glen Cloy from Forestry and Land Scotland. This pilot project will allow us to:
• Develop a prototype for sustainable woodland management
• Create woodland crofting opportunities with affordable housing
• Restore native woodland and enhance biodiversity
• Protect archaeological features and cultural heritage
• Improve water management to reduce flood risk

sections.heading: We aim to (amongst other aims!)
content: Secure by community asset transfer, and conserve, expand and connect areas of remaining ancient woodland for conservation, community access and regenerative land management, outdoor activities and education
Maintain and improve waterways within these woodland both for research, community enjoyment and conservation, but also flood mitigation purposes for our village communities at risk of coastal erosion
To investigate further, and preserve and protect, our cultural monuments throughout this highly rich and under-researched landscape

To develop low impact, sustainable and environmentally friendly 'green' homes for primary sector workers on the island, with an emphasis on affordability, using local materials and vernacular Arran design, and inspired by the HiFar initiative.

"Dùthchas" is a Gaelic word that encompasses a deep connection to land, heritage, and community—embodying our relationship with Arran and our responsibility to care for it. Learn more about dùthchas in this article: Dùthchas - What are we actually talking about?
